html:
• S&P 500 and Nasdaq rise, Dow falls
  • Tech biggest S&P sector gainer; financials down most
  • Gold, dollar up; crude, bitcoin down
  • U.S. 10-year Treasury yield ~1.52%

Nov 4 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of markets brought to you by Reuters reporters. You can share your thoughts with us at markets.research@thomsonreuters.com



CHIPMAKERS PUSH S&P 500 AND NASDAQ TO RECORD HIGH CLOSES (1604 EDT/2005 GMT)

The S&P 500 .SPX and Nasdaq .IXIC closed at record high levels on Thursday, powered by double-digit percentage gains chipmakers Qualcomm and Nvidia.

Qualcomm QCOM.O surged nearly 13% after the company provided a stronger than expected outlook, fueled by soaring demand for chips used in phones, cars and other internet-connected devices. (Full Story)

Nvidia NVDA.O soared 12% to a record high after Wells Fargo increased its price target on the company, arguing the graphics chipmaker will become a major player in the upcoming so-called metaverse.

The S&P 500 and Nasdaq's have now set record high closes for six straight sessions.

The S&P 500 consumer discretionary index .SPLRCD jumped 1.5%, lifted by 2.75% jump in Amazon AMZN.O. The technology index .SPLRCT rallied 1.5%.

On the downside, the financials index .SPSY sank about 1.3%, with investors unwinding expectations of quicker Fed rate hikes a day after the central bank signalled it was in no hurry to do so. (Full Story)

The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended lower.

With Thursday's gains, the S&P 500 is up almost 25% in 2021 and the Nasdaq has gained nearly 24%.

The Philadelphia chip index .SOX jumped 3.5% for the session and it is now up 33% year to date.

Here is your closing snapshot:


(Noel Randewich)

*****


QUALCOMM AND NVIDIA LEAD BIG SURGE IN CHIPS (1346 EDT/1746 GMT)

Semiconductor stocks are surging to fresh record highs on Thursday, lifted industry heavyweights Qualcomm QCOM.O and Nvidia NVDA.O, both surging over 11%.

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index .SOX jumped 3% to its highest level ever. It is now up 7% over the past week and up 32% year to date.

With efforts to diversify beyond smartphones paying off, Qualcomm's forecasts late on Wednesday for revenue and earnings both exceeded analysts' expectations. (Full Story)

Several analysts raised their Qualcomm price targets, with the mean target now at $187, compared to $179 before the company's quarterly report. Qualcomm last traded up 13.2% at about $157.

Nvidia surged 13% to a record high after Wells Fargo increased its price target on the graphic chipmaker to $320, the highest among over 40 analysts tracked by Refinitiv.

In his report, Wells Fargo analyst Aaron Rakers said development of an immersive 3D "Metaverse" across industry, design and manufacturing could equate to a $10 billion opportunity for Nvidia over the next five years.

Wondering what exactly this so-called Metaverse is? Raker defines it as, "a persistent, synchronous successor to the mobile internet where users will interact with virtual 3D assets across a variety of platforms."

Last trading at $300, NVDA has surged over 25% since Meta Platforms FB.O, previously called Facebook, on Oct. 25 said it would increase its capex by billions of dollars to built out its virtual reality metaverse. (Full Story)

On the downside, Qorvo QRVO.O tumbled 14% after the Apple AAPL.O supplier gave a soft December-quarter outlook, with at least four brokerages cutting their price targets.


(Noel Randewich)

*****


THE IPO WINDOW IS WIDE OPEN; THAT'S GOOD NEWS FOR EQUITY RETURNS (1300 EDT/1700 GMT)

As IPO bankers scurry to price as many deals as possible before year-end, Jessica Rabe, co-founder of DataTrek Research, sees this cycle as a driver of long-term equity returns.

Rabe points out that 2021 has been a record year for U.S. IPO volume with more than 350 offerings, up 60 percent from last year and a 5-year high, citing data from Crunchbase and Renaissance Capital. And she notes that companies have raised over $165 billion in proceeds so far, over double the amount raised last year.

She reiterates the importance of venture capital funding for eventual exits into public equity markets.

Without fresh, disruptive blood in the system, Rabe says, U.S. stocks are limited to whatever more mature companies can generate in terms of earnings growth. Getting novel business models into public hands is the difference between 5-7 percent long-run annual returns and +10 percent, she says.

Rabe notes that more companies are expected to list soon, including electric car maker Rivian RIVN.O, business communication platform Weave WEAV.N and fintech NerdWallet Inc NRDS.O.

"Bottom line: The IPO window is wide open and should be for the foreseeable future, especially with US equities continuing to reach record highs," Rabe writes.

In addition, while financials continue to have the lowest valuations of any S&P 500 sector, she says, more innovative financial platforms going public is encouraging.

Indeed, NerdWallet's shares are soaring more than 60% on Thursday in the personal finance firm's strong market debut. (Full Story)

Next week, Rivian, backed by both Amazon.com AMZN.O and Ford Motor Co F.N, looks to raise more than $8 billion in one of this year's most hotly anticipated IPOs. (Full Story)

(Lance Tupper)

*****


EUROPE’S FOURTH ALL-TIME HIGH: WHAT’S NEXT? (1221 EDT/1621 GMT)

European equities hit a new record high for the fourth straight session as worries about earlier-than-expected monetary policy tightening by central banks faded.

The Reserve Bank of Australia rejected market talk of an early rate hike on Tuesday, driving bond yields down and boosting risk sentiment across the board. It was followed by “a patient” Federal Reserve on Wednesday and a Bank of England, which kept rates on hold today.

The European real estate stock index .SX86P is the best performer on the Stoxx 600, while bank stocks .SX7P lost around 2%, on a lower for longer rates scenario.

Investors are wondering what will happen next as the Stoxx 600 is again in uncharted territory.

Some analysts seem to agree that the bullish mood could last until year-end, with a possible increase in volatility. But 2022 will be more challenging, with central banks unwinding their monetary stimulus amid supply chain disruptions and economic growth uncertainties.


(Stefano Rebaudo)

*****


GLOBAL MARKET CAP DOUBLED SINCE COVID-19 CRASH (1155 EDT/1555 GMT)

The Fed pulling off a tantrum-free tapering announcement definitely marks a new chapter in the COVID-19 policy response.

All in all, it's fair to say that as far as global stock markets are concerned, monetary and fiscal stimulus were pretty effective to lift off markets after the pandemic crash.

As you can see below, global market cap doubled to $69 trillion since March 2020.


(Marc Jones with Julien Ponthus)

*****



THURSDAY DATA MAKES NICE WITH THE FED, WITH A FEW SURPRISES (1105 EDT/1505 GMT)

Data released on Thursday politely supported Fed Chair Jerome Powell's remarks made a day earlier about the labor market reaching the end of its long, rocky road to recovery sometime around the middle of next year.

The number of U.S. workers filing first-time applications for unemployment benefits dropped last week to the lowest level since the moment before mandates to halt the emerging pandemic plunged the economy into its steepest freefall in history.

Jobless claims USJOB=ECI dipped 4.9% to 269,000, the smallest number since March 2020, the calm before the COVID storm that sent new unemployment applications sky-rocketing to a head-spinning 6.149 million. (Full Story)

With this, even with ongoing hobbled supply chains and labor shortages, claims are now at the upper end of the range associated with healthy labor market churn.

While the report falls outside the survey period for the Labor Department's hotly anticipated jobs report due tomorrow, it has the appearance of a welcome return to pre-pandemic 'normal.'

The 4-week moving average of jobless claims slipped to about 285,000, and ongoing claims USJOBN=ECI dropped more than expected to 2.105 million.

Still, that's high. For context, the number of Americans collecting unemployment benefits for two weeks or more could nearly populate the city of Houston.

And in a surreal sign of the times, U.S. companies are ramping up mass layoffs despite the labor shortage as employers are handing out big piles of pink slips to workers who refuse to get vaccinated.

Executive outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas released its planned layoffs report for October USCHAL=ECI, which showed pre-announced severance increased by 27.5% to 22,822. A whopping 22% of those layoffs were COVID jab refuseniks.

"We know companies are holding tight to their workers and are in fact looking for workers," writes Andrew Challenger, senior vice president at Challenger Gray. "However, we also know that for many employers, a federal vaccine mandate from OSHA is forthcoming, and for many government employees and contractors, as well as for health care providers, mandates already exist. This complicates hiring and retention efforts."

Next, the busy Labor Department delivered the morning's biggest surprises with its revised third-quarter labor costs and productivity data.

Labor cost growth USLCP=ECI shifted into high gear, accelerating to an 8.3% quarterly annualized growth rate from the prior quarter's 1% increase, coming in well above the 7% analysts expected. (Full Story)

And productivity USPROP=ECI reversed course, dropping an even 5% after gaining 2.3% in the second quarter.

"The biggest drop in productivity since 1981 is a consequence of the Delta Covid hit to growth, and it tells us nothing about the underlying trend," says Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics. "We remain optimistic that productivity growth will average 2%-plus over the next couple years, at least."

We'll have more opportunity to read the labor market tea leaves when the October jobs report is released Friday, which is expected to show a payrolls gain of 450,000 and an unemployment rate inching down to 4.7%.

So let's talk about the trade gap USTBAL=ECI, which widened by 11.1% in September to a record high $80.9 billion, according to the Commerce Department.

The move was driven by a sharp drop in demand for U.S. exports even as domestic consumption pushed imports higher.

"The September trade data supports our view that supply-driven trade disruptions will persist well into 2022," says Mahir Rasheed, U.S. economist at Oxford Economics. "With US consumption still firmly ahead of foreign demand, the trade deficit is poised to remain historically elevated until supply disruptions ease and faster vaccine diffusion mitigates health risks from the pandemic."

The closely-watched deficit in the value of goods exported to and imported from China grew to $36.5 billion.

Wall Street hates surprises, so the largely inline macroeconomics of the day kept the S&P 500 and Nasdaq on course for their sixth straight record closing highs.

Financials .SPSY and healthcare .SPXHC, however, helped weight the Dow into the red.

(Stephen Culp)

*****


WALL STREET OPENS WITH A 'MEH' (0950 EDT/1350 GMT)

Wall Street seemed reluctant to leave the starting gate after the opening bell on Thursday, embarking on a session wedged betwixt the week's most anticipated events - the conclusion of the U.S. Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting and the October employment report due on Friday.

At present, the bellwether S&P 500 and the tech-laden Nasdaq were setting a very tentative course for their sixth consecutive record closing highs. The blue-chip Dow was most recently slightly red, on course to snap its four-day winning streak.

A swath of economic data released an hour before the bell came in largely in line with expectations, with jobless claims falling to a 19-month low and the trade gap widening more than anticipated.

Perhaps the biggest surprise was delivered by the Commerce Department's third quarter labor cost growth hotter-than-expected print, and the larger-than-anticipated drop in productivity.

Labor costs, in the form of wage growth, will be a closely watched element of tomorrow's jobs report, as it's a solid indicator regarding the Fed's "transitory" inflation assurances.

On the earnings front, Moderna MRNA.O slashed its 2021 sales forecast for its COVID-19 jab as the drugmaker struggles ramp up production of the vaccine. (Full Story)

Corn flake maker Kellogg Co K.N warned its full-year earnings could be affected by ongoing worker strikes at its cereal plants. (Full Story)

The third-quarter earnings season is nearing the final bend, with roughly one-fifth of the companies in the S&P 500 yet to report. Of those who have, about 81% have beaten consensus, and analysts now see year-on-year third quarter earnings growth of 40.4%, up from the 29.4% seen at the first of the month, according to Refinitiv I/B/E/S.

Here is your opening snapshot:

(Stephen Culp)

*****


FOR LIVE MARKET POSTS PRIOR TO 0930 EDT, PLEASE CLICK HERE: (Full Story)


(Lance Tupper is a Reuters market analyst. The views expressed are his own)
